I would like to give my 2 cents contribution: many years ago, when I was a high school student, during chemistry lesson I performed several “Flame test” (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flame_test). Despite the fact that it was more than 20 years ago, I can clearly remember the “strong suggestion” of our teacher: “when you pick up the salt to be analysed, or when you wash the wire sampler, pay attention to don’t scratch the glass support with the stainless steel, or it will be permanently contaminated by sodium present in the glass”.
This was the main mistake of all students: we were using a nichrome wire (stainless steel) to perform the test, and it was very easy to touch (and scratch) the Test tube containing the acid for the cleaning operation. All consequently salt analysis were yellow, due to the sodium contamination of the glass (basically the silica used to prepare the glass).

In other words: yes, another confirmation that the plasma is yellow due to the beaker silica contamination.

Thanks very much for your video, it’s really inspiring!

Thanks for sharing this great DIY science. You solved several problems on the way to solving the colour mystery. Those answers help others better understand how to do microwave plasma research on a tight budget. Understanding hot spots, protecting the oven, recording observations.
Physicists have spent trillions of dollars researching plasma and trying to contain it. Perhaps if they had been given a micro budget and a few microwaves they would be much closer to understanding sustainable plasma containment than they currently are.
The next step could be to modify the oven cavity to obtain a stable standing wave with a small volume experiencing intense constructive interference. I am sure that would be very dangerous and don't recommend anyone doing it outside a shielded safe space.
I have seen that there are some research papers on computer modelling microwave cavities for the purpose of chemistry and CVD, so hopefully we might see mini microwave fusion reactors which actually produce useful power even before giant fusion reactors work. Or perhaps, someone can explain what the challenges would be to produce a mini microwave plasma based nuclear reactor?
And finally you showed how useful it is to collaborate with others when you thought you couldn't find the source of the sodium ions: It forced you to share ideas with others and their insights helped you to complete the investigation. Therefore, you demonstrated *the importance of collaborative problem solving*.

Also, the reason the plasma fizzles out at 3:05 is because most microwaves don’t actually run all the time due to a rated 50% duty cycle on the magnetron with a typical time base of 10 seconds (so 5 seconds on, 5 seconds off) for commercial/home microwaves. One clarification: you mentioned a couple times that the peaks should indicate the colors your seeing. This isn't totally accurate; the width of the peaks in the spectrum is also very important. In fact, what you really want to look at is the area under the curve. For example, a higher peaking but really narrow red line might give off less energy than a broad, shorter yellow line.

At one point, you had blue plasma, but no lines in the blue. This was because of the blue peaked blackbody continuum, which is wide and diffuse, but has more energy in it when you integrate across all wavelengths, leading to the blue color. (although there's some interpretation from the eyes too, but we can ignore that).

Anyway, maybe you were just simplifying this explanation for the video, but I just wanted to clarify as you sounded a little confused about it.

There is that annoying potassium again. That stuff is kalium. You know, K for kalium. It is not P for potassium. Even if the Dutch used to call it potas centuries ago, that does not mean potassium is the right name. It is too long, considering you can call it kalium. Get real, you are doing it wrong. You could start calling natrium kitchensaltium or even sodium. Just as absurd, huh?
W H Y ? !
Why can't the entire world start using the most practical names? We share the periodic table, why don't we stick to the names in the periodic table? All the rest is only confusing. Plumbum is also called lead. Why? Everybody can understand plumbum. Let us forget nonsense like lead, sodium, potassium. Other languages have such words, too. Gold, silver, copper, you can easily translate that list of words, and some words will surprise you. I'm really not just blaming the US, jusr because I went to school in Europe. ALL our chemical nicknames are for books. That is for the past. For better communication worldwide, drop those nicknames. Again, why not?! Everything in the world has over 150 words for it. Why can't we uniform the chemical words? It is not only the elements, there is also a huge number of compounds that are mislabeled. Take acidic acid. What is that? Sourish sour? Huh? Don't you got a better name?

Years go by. Decades go by. Centuries go by. And everybody is so proud of the progress of science. But meanwhile, when you hear somebody speaking in another language, chances are, the chemistry between you is fading very soon. What is he talking about?! They don't even have the same elements as you. You need to know too much for comfort. Isn't that awkward?

It's a lot simpler than you think.  A lot of these plasmas arise, not because of absorbtion, but because something conductive acts like an antenna, generates a high voltage across itself, generating a spark - and once you have a spark, i.e. plasma, it grows and sustains itself. holy craps. your deduction process is awesome but you also jogged out a piece of memory relevant.

let's go back in time, when incandescent light sources were generating 10lm/W, fluorescent (with good ballast) was 40lm/W, and HID or sodium vapors were 80lm/W. LEDs were promised to overtake and all (and in fact they have exceeded 120lm/W in a couple of years). But way back then, when light sources were fighting it out, one of the answers was a microwave driven light source. Because of the way that it worked, you didn't have anything like filament burnout and in theory they were perhaps capable of hitting 100k hours MTBF like LEDs (save for the magnetron) while generating numbers similar to sodium vapor lamps in terms of photometric efficiency. i do believe that the microwave driven method had at least one patent associated with it. if i find it i'll kick it your way.

so don't kid yourself. this was considered at one point a competitive way to generate light.

Verry interesting experiments.
Some time ago I was looking for a cheap microwave because I wanted to find out whether microwaves can be sufficient to cause unstable elements to decay.

The problem is that microwaves alone are sufficient to cause the usual measuring instruments for radioactive decay to indicate a decay that was only triggered by the microwave radiation, because the 400 volt voltage of the measuring probe is influenced by the microwaves.

The problem is that one cannot be sure whether a radioactive decay or a disturbance of the measuring field (400 volts) occurred directly through microwaves.

Newer measuring sensors work on the basis of semiconductors and typical digital photo technology. But even there, it is possible that an apparent decay event could be triggered directly by the microwaves, in that reactions with the air gas or other elements of the microwave or the material sample with radioactive elements (e.g. tobacco) lead to a triggering via sensor activation.

This video is amazing. Some physics related comments that might help others:
• a (physics) plasma is an ionized gas.
• a physics plasma has no relation to blood plasma.
• a general plasma consists of three "species": free electrons, ions, and neutral molecules.
• plasmas conduct electricity, due to the presence of free electrons and ions.
• Inside of neon lights, florescent lights, and sodium vapor lamps is a plasma.
• The sun (and stars in general), lightning bolts, sparks and the aurora borealis are plasmas.
• A flame will generate a plasma if it is hot enough.
• The microwave electric and magnetic fields cause electric currents in the plasma, which induce a fluid velocity of the plasma particles (ie free electrons and ions). Particle collisions convert this fluid velocity to random thermal velocity increasing the temperature. The collisions between high energy ions or free electrons and a neutral molecule cause further ionization. Due to these phenomena, the microwaves replenish the plasma and allow it to persist.

Look for the stars!!  There is no sodium contamination.  Adding water was reduced to the system temperature.  “The temperature of a star's outer layers defines how we perceive its color from the Earth's surface.  Not-too-hot stars (about 3,000 Kelvin) look red.  Yellow stars, like the Sun, have a temperature of around 6,000 Kelvin;  and the warmest are white or blue because their temperature is above 10,000 Kelvin.  A star emits energy at all wavelengths, but not to the same degree.  There is a peak in its radiance for each temperature.  An amount of energy that will determine the predominant color of the star.  That's why there are no green stars.  In principle, there should be stars in all colors of the rainbow (red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo and violet).  But, when this color sequence is obtained as a function of the temperature of incandescent objects, the energy of white overlaps with green. ”  Costa, J. R. V.

the reason i think you should not put metal in the microwave is (if there is a better expert out there who knows better and can chime in)

the metal acts like wire in a transformer and using induction turns the microwaves back into electric at the microwave frequency.

then the metal electrically charged turns the electric back into microwaves and maybe cycles and sends the beam back to the magnetron or puts such a load on it that it will destroy it.

in the first microwaves since it's invention maybe the magnetron was easier to destroy but today's microwaves are a little more robust.

another thing dont use a good microwave for experiments but rather use a junker because some experiments can dirty up the inside and possible ruin it

Sadly to save money most older microwaves  use a rather small (1-2uF) capacitor in the voltage doubler for the magnetron (instead of using full wave rectification, a 3400vac transformer, and hundreds of uF to keep the ripple below a few %) = DC with a huge amount of ripple. It still cooks food good enough, so manufactures penny pinch wherever they can (to the point aluminum is also used in the transformer windings, and will generally fry if you leave the micro running for more than an hour at 100%).

I'm sorry if these are repeat suggestions...

1. Quartz instead of glass. That can get expensive, but perhaps gluing a layer of powdered quartz on the inside of the glass, just around the bottom (top when inverted) for an inch or two, and the full bottom surface, so as to minimize the foggy view.

2. You can get quartz slides, and make an optically decent window using even a good crystal sample of quartz, just toward the camera, ground quartz everywhere else.

3. Contain, or isolate the plasma from the glass using a magnetic field, or fields. I don't know right offhand, how to set this, exactly. Clearly, the easy ways have immediate problems, such as putting permanent magnets or even a coil or two and running the wires out another siliconed hole, so as to avoid arcing. The surface of glass (made from soda-line) usually crystallizes (through the process of weatherization) into sodium carbonate (Na2CO3).  This is usually treated at manufacturing time for aesthetic purposes through process called anti-blooming where fluorine gas is injected into the still hot glass vessel. This process reduces the amount of  bloom by a factor of ten. But the sodium carbonate still exists.

Please, consider:
1. The microwave oven is microwave at specific freq. (~2.45 MHz), because it's tuned to heat water molecules. It will transfer energy to other molecules differently, but most probably not as good as to water. Have an electromagnetic heater with constant (not pulsating) energy flow and controllable frequency instead of pulsating magnetron.
2. Obviously, everything in the experiment is contributing to light spectrum coming from it: air with everything in it, container, initial gas provider. Do it in a vacuum in a crystal glass container pre-filled with specific substance(s).
3. Choose a substance with low ionization energy. You don't have to ionize it completely. Apply appropriate wave frequency and power to the desired state of substance.

Dude, 'normal' "floated" glass and optical grade silica quartz glass have trace amounts of sodium, but chemistry glassware contains A LOT of sodium... One of the constituent components of modern borosilicate glassware is soda ash: aka sodium carbonate ;) and its not intended for making plasma in a microwave. If you heat that red hot and microwave it you can melt the glass. Instead of heating it outside with a torch first your heating it with plasma inside - but your still disrupting and vaporizing the structure of the molecules on the surface, releasing sodium ions.

Spoiler Warning Man, while watching this, I kept thinking to a story my Molecular Bio professor told me about how a lab that specialized in cell cultures moved or got bought out, and after they moved they couldn't get the cell cultures to grow to save their lives. After trying everything (including importing water from their original sources), it turned out that they started using different glassware at the new location, and it had different trace elements which was screwing over their ability to grow the cultures.

So, needless to say, I was pretty tickled when it turned out to be the glassware :P

(Also, just goes to show that low-probability variables are still variables)

These are very interesting experiments. The microwave plasma exhibits strange and peculiar properties. First, we must consider some details to solve the mysteries. The plasma color not only depends on the chemical components, but also on the emission generated by the energy released by the plasma resonance. This is difficult to calculate because we must solve the Maxwell’s equations into a specific shape and conditions. As we can see in the video, when the plasma is contained into the glass a better stability is shown. It could be produced due to the container geometry, which can work as a resonance box as well when the plasma gets into a resonance state.



Another detail is that plasma is a very efficient tool to clean surfaces. Is widely used to clean the interior of high vacuum chambers in industry. When the plasma gets in contact over a determined surface, the plasma “vaporizes” the impurities over the surface. This is a common problem in experimental thermonuclear assemblies, in which the plasma is maintain away from the vacuum chamber walls by high magnetic fields induced by powerful coils. This is to avoid contamination into the thermonuclear plasma. In the case of the experiments showed in the video, the plasma gets in contact with the glass walls, so it doesn’t matter how much you “clean” the glass, contamination is inevitable.



Maybe should be a good idea to repeat these experiments but now trying to get more data to solve the following questions: Can we measure the temperature inside the plasma ball? plasma temperature gives us important information about their conditions. How much the plasma depends on the atmospheric conditions? Is well know that in lower pressures is more easy to form plasma conditions but here.. what is happening? And also, we know the magnetron frequency, the power emission, the resonance frequency of the oven, the geometry of the glass and an approximate volume of the plasma ball, so, Can we simulate/solve the Maxwell’s equations of the plasma ball? this is in order to determine the resonance emission and more magnetohydrodynamic properties.



Another thing… Could you share the resulting spectrum data emissions? Could be interesting to analyze this information, maybe I can find something else.

Regards.

Nile,
((first after reading what I wrote I feel I came off as being critical of you and I apologize if thats how I come off to you. Just friendly advise from a old lab tech who enjoyed your Lil' experiment!))
I have to say (though I've not yet watched to the end, at about15 min mark) I think your assuming the yellow is from sodium. And that's poor science. First, did you get a base line spectrum on the materials/gases existing in every plasma? And.... Was that the main goal of this "experiment", to discover what compounds cause color changes in plasma??? I originally thought your "Microwave/Plasma" experiment was pretty cool! ANd I still do, only that your tangent on why it was yellow for me kinda ruined the whole microwave/plasma ordeal. (well, maybe not ruined the whole deal. Just the wrong focus) Oh by the way when you struggled to reproduce the plasma after removing the rotation factor, I think you jumped to conclusions with rotation when, in my opinion, it was quite possibly height that made the difference!! With the glass turn table turned over your object was then over an inch higher in the microwave cabinet!And as you learned the microwaves travel through the inside of the cabinet in somewhat of a pattern. And it's a repeatable pattern which is why the turntable is important when heating food! I'm willing to bet if you were to lower your objective (or sample and beaker) to near orig height and didn't rotate it, you'd once again see the plasma return! If you dont think im full of it and are willing to try it I'd love to find out if I am right or not! Now having watched it all I do think you jump to alot of conclusions...but still I think we both learned alot from everything you did, And... it was fun!! All in all I got to say, Good job man!
Question though: do you know if your microwave had a rotating deflector above the cabinet ceiling or not? Oh, and when your rotating attachment kept catching fire...well once you burnt it you put carbon traces all over it and then it was doomed to relight every time! (I have a lot of microwave oven experience/knowledge as a repair tech. But hey, If I can help by answering any questions about ovens or microwaves I'm happy to help!)

Yeah, sodium peaks show up in almost everything, because sodium is effectively everywhere, and its yellow peak is very intense.
(guesswork begins here)
Even ignoring that glass has sodium in it, I would still be willing to assume that your glassware just wasn't perfectly clean, and the sodium was coming from residue on the glass. Another important note, is that the incandescence you referred to actually still follows the same emission spectra as other sources of excitation, and so "soot" wouldn't really explain a sodium peak, except for the fact that your soot contains sodium.As for where the plasma is coming from, and how it's sustained, I'd say it's pretty obvious that the initial sparking of the metal is coming from current being induced in the metal by the changing magnetic field of the microwave, which actually helps to explain how the plasma ball is sustained, and why it happens with fire as well. Plasma is relatively conductive, so a current can be induced in it by a changing magnetic field, just like in metal, this current helps to sustain the plasma, and in some cases make it bigger, which makes a larger conductor, which is in contact with more changing magnetic field. This also explains why the plasma breaks away from the fuel source, it's no longer "fire" sustained by fuel, it's free plasma sustained by a magnetic field. If I'm right about this, the plasma ball would be an inductively coupled plasma, as described:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inductively_coupled_plasma

ok...  where to begin...  the beaker is not "incredibly hot" because you are confusing temperature with heat.  yes, the temperature of the plasma is very high, but it has VERY little mass, therefore it contains only a small quantity of heat.  the enormously larger heat capacity of the glass beaker means that the small quantity of heat will only raise the temperature of the glass a minimal amount.  using a new beaker each time to "protect" the beaker also makes little sense.  what cracks glass is thermal shock, so exposing a preheated beaker to plasma actually means it would be LESS likely to shatter, compared to using a cold beaker.
Just vapour that is all

there are traces of sodium EVERYWHERE, and the sodium D line is SO strong, and requires such an infinitesimal amt of sodium, it's EXTREMELY difficult to eliminate.  stick just about anything in a flame and the flame emits the the sodium D line.  intro lab experiments demonstrating salt bead flame tests require that the platinum wire used be dipped in pure conc nitric acid and brought to red heat in a flame REPEATEDLY just to get rid of the ubiquitous sodium D line before testing other salts is possible.
If you can manage to get a quartz tube from a semiconductor doping furnace, you can have boron, phosphorous, or more exotic contaminants.  Be aware there could be arsenic.

The ripple frequency heard is 60 Hz actually, since every second half-wave is shorted out by a diode in the high voltage circuit, for rectifying AC into pulsing DC for the magnetron. As a suggestion, try perhaps gypsum plaster (CaSO4), Copper, non-ROHS solder, Magnesium. Be cautious of the fumes. I also suggest investigating four mysteries: 1) why Aluminium only creates blue plasma in electric plasma, and why that color won't show up while it's burning, or in flame tests. 2) Why copper almost acts the opposite way, and its blue-green color doesn't readily show up in an electric arc of up to about .5 Amp, but it can be seen in flame tests. 3) Color of magnesium in electric plasma, if there's any. 4) That's probably the most challenging to reproduce (and it's okay if you pass this one). You often see this briliant blue-green color in high amperage high voltage arcs. I keep wondering if that's always because of the copper content of the conductor.

I wanna suggest way of making indigo carmine which needs much less cleanings. First step is just indigo and sulfuric acid reaction. After you need pour it in cold water with cracked ice, all heat of diluting sulfuric acid goes to ice melting and blend stays completely cold. Neutralize extra acid with sodium bicarbonate and add some sodium sulfate. Put it in fridge for a night and filter it with coffee filter. Final step is dissolving it in hot water ( you can do that with product on coffee filter, just take it off when all diluted, that makes lesser loss ). Add 1:1 or 1:2 isopropanol and put it in fridge. Filter it with coffee filter and wash with some extra isopropanol. And while it still pasty put in into a bowl to dry. Done, thanks for reading :3

Your understanding of "leakage" in a microwave system is incorrect. Microwaves leak out the front glass all the time, they just don't do so with any coherency to their waveform. The mesh doesn't "block" or "reflect" the radiation, it simply shreds it. To do this it MUST have a charge put upon it and that is what the little precise gap at the corner of the door is for; to turn the perforated sheet in the door into a capacitance device. So the amount of energy that leaks out the grid on the door is roughly equivalent to the ratio of hole metal but it causes the waveforms to interact in a self-defeating manner. Microwaves generate heat by resonating molecules (not just water!) so if they cannot coherently resonate something on the other side of the grid it appears to "block" the energy but does not. Think of it as equivalent to how they turn large waves into a weaker choppy surface in harbor areas, like how marsh slows flow.

I think what may be happening is microwave based plasmas are actually nonthermal plasmas. This would explain the fairly low heat of the glass, as plasmas are usually stable at tens of thousands of Kelvin. The microwaves are likely inducing an electromagnetic field, which can induce a nonthermal equilibrium. This will allow the electrons to be incredibly hot and allow a plasmatic state, whilst their mass is so insignificant to the mass of the protons and neutrons. Thus, the overall temperature of the plasma system is pretty much room temperature, ±100 K.

When you put only metal or nothing in a microwave and let it work, there is little to no absorption of microwave energy in the chamber. Even you see sparks coming out of the forks for example, it's only the transient high electric field ionizing the air, but there shouldn't be too much energy transferred to avalanche events. The metal itself won't absorb literally any microwave because they are ideal conductors. What all this means is the standing wave ratio of an empty chamber is really high, and most microwave energy goes back to the magnetron, the microwave source. It's okay for a household microwave to take like a few seconds of "no load" working, but the source will finally be damaged due to overheating. Over time, you will see the oven won't heat up things as fast as a new one would.

Ok, this is going to be a really, really dumb idea, but... the typical microwave oven uses a voltage doubler circuit which has a 50% duty cycle output. Because it's cheap. Which means it is possible - not difficult at all - to rewire them to double the power. You will require one additional high-voltage diode and one additional high-voltage capacitor, both of which can be obtained by sacrificing another microwave, and an electronics enthusiast who will carry out this reckless modification. It should substantially improve your plasma, as well as grant you the ability to microwave a baked alaska.

This is an excellent rigorous analysis but I don't think I agree with the conclusion that the blue (non-aluminum) plasma is from superhot soot. The temperatures needed to achieve blue heat are PHENOMENALLY HIGH and are going to burn away any soot particles to CO2 immediately. A far more likely explanation is simply the vibronically coupled lines of nitrogen and ionized nitrogen in air. It's blue for the same reason lightning and sparks are blue. You even can see some of these lines on the spectra you took a few times.

Greeeeeeaatt video. At the end...during talking about why it was 120Hz, I feel a detail could have been added and then expanded upon that might be kinda interesting. You didn't mention whether this was a newer solid state microwave, or the older and much more common standard microwave(with just a diode/capacitive doubler) . The latter would be a likely be that the magnetron is being ran on unfiltered pulsed DC and so is, in your case, 120Hz rectified AC (it's 100 for us in the UK, ofc) and then chucks out something like 2.45GHz into the cavity 120 times a second (uhh, dusty area of brain memory information, please correct if all or any is incorrect.) Varying that frequency might give you some interesting results (if a total pain).
I'm not sure if the more modern solid state microwaves still operate in the same way(err minus the whole bit before actually powering the magnetron), or still pump the magnetron with totally unfiltered pulsed DC like that. That miiiiiight be worth looking at, and might give you more scope for fiddling with the output and seeing what happens and if it's anything cool. Just do it very fucking carefully ahaha. 'However, my biggest concern wasn't really safety' will absolutely get you killed if you're playing around on the inside of the microwave, too...or operate the magnetron out of the/a cavity...y'know, the fun stuff :p

24:12 This must mean that plasma has no actual sound (or at least none recorded at this time) but what we heard was the displacement of air. I'm sure of it actually.

There is this nifty thing (that I advise nobody to do) you can do with a lighter, and a bottle.

Place said lighter into bottle mouth, and press the fork down. The butane is heavier than air, so it will drop to the bottom of the bottle (which, theoretically should be making a sound at this point, but it would be a very low hertz, using this method).

Once sufficiently filled, remove the lighter, and light it. Slowly tilt the bottle towards the flame.

As the heavier gas leaves the bottle, it will ignite on the lighters flame, and then it will backdraft into the bottle. (I have had a bottle explode, DON'T DO THIS).

When it does, there is a large displacement of air and gas, making a sound similar to what was heard in this video. Bottles, because of their neck, will also hum a note, that rises in pitch as the butane is burned off.

And that's that, folks.

a great way to save your fingers is thus
step 1: use some kind of goey, relatively weak adhesive or polymer to remove all loose peices of glass & glass powder, you may need to use tweezers to remove some pieces if they are jammed,
step 2: clean glass using nonconductive cleaning solution (whatever you have that evaporates quickly will do)
step 3: buy a standard screen protector, this is your fingersaver. steps 1&2 are to ensure that the adhesion is not interfered with by loose shards of glass

I was yelling at my tablet for a couple minutes that the sodium was coming from the glass 🤓 I work on excimer lasers, which run on Krypton/Fluorine, Argon/Fluorine and Xenon Chloride plasma.   It's critical to make any plasma 'container' out of extremely non-reactive elements to avoid contaminating the lasing gas, and nickel is the material of choice for that.   Of course you need an optical material that's non-reactive as well, and the common optical material in a laser tube/chamber are crystalline Calcium Fluoride (CaF2) and Aluminum Oxide (Al2O3).  They are probably way more expensive than you would want to use for a youtube video, but they are translucent and will not release any gaseous contaminants into your plasma.

Runtime[edit]

In Field Reversed Configurations, the longest run time is 300 ms, set by the Princeton Field Reversed Configuration in August 2016.[55] However this involved no fusion. 

Q[edit]

The ratio of energy extracted against the amount of energy supplied. This record is considered to be set by the Joint European Torus (JET) in 1997 when the device extracted 16 MW of power.[54] However, this ratio can be seen three different ways.

0.69 is the actual point in time ratio between ”fusion power” and actual input power in the plasma (23 MW).
0.069 is the ratio between the “fusion” power and the power required to produce the 23MW input power (essentially it takes into account the efficiency of the NB system).
0.0069 is the ratio between the “fusion” power and the total peak power required for a JET pulse. This takes into account all the power from the grid plus the one from the two large JET flywheel generators.[citation needed]

I think there are 2 possible explanations for the noise, one is that the plasma itself is emitting sound, it certainly has enough power to make those beakers dance around, so it's no stretch to assume it is emitting sound.  Another component would be the microwave transformer groaning due to the VSWR mismatch caused by the plasma generation.  It's 120Hz because the 2000v from the microwave transformer is being rectified by a full wave rectifier, causing voltage spikes twice for every input cycle.  This is also why Microwaves "burn out" due to experiments -- they are unable to to handle the reflected power caused by the impedance mismatch.  Many modern microwaves have impedance matching circuits to deal with unconventional packaging and the odd fork left on a plate.

When plasma is involved in the formation of certain chemical species, it is commonly understood as atom/ion recombination. The nitrogen molecules form atomic and ionic nitrogen, I.e. N and N+. The blue color you showed in the video should be attributed to the emission lines of nitrogen in the UV and blue region. In this case, you proposed reaction mechanism for the formation of NO2 becomes questionable.
From your spectra, when the plasma turned blue, the broadband emission dominated the spectra. Also there was the 500 nm line. This suggested the plasma was breaking nitrogen and giving N II line. That means the plasma temperature got really high. But in plasma, the temperature often refers to electron temperature rather than translational temperature. These two things should not be confused with each other. Plank model might not be a good choice.

As I was watching and you kept observing the peaks in your spectra characteristic of sodium ions, I started thinking, "Why isn't he considering the beaker as a possible source of the sodium?"

If you don't have much of a materials science or industrial glass background, it might not occur to you. It's actually common to expose glass to baths of molten alkali or alkaline earth metals in order to change the physical properties of the resulting glass. Once the metals are dissolved into the glass, they can dramatically increase the strength, ductility, and shock resistance of the result. I'm not familiar with the process used to produce lab beakers, but it seemed like a good bet that the glass was treated with molten sodium at some point (or sodium or a salt of sodium was added by some other means) and that during your experiments, some of the sodium was ionizing and vaporizing (or vice versa), thus contributing to the emission spectra you observed.

I kept waiting for it to happen . . . and then, voila! There you have it, Bob's your uncle.

It's been a while since one of my hypotheses was not also obvious to the investigator! Thank you for a fun mystery and sharing it with us so we could play science sleuth with you.

Are you familiar with high vacuum processes? What you are doing is "sputtering", which is the knocking off of atoms from a substrate by ion bombardment at or near room temperature. This is the scheme most electronic integrated circuits are made (to apply thin coatings). The substrate being etched must be the cathode, attracting positive ions, which are accelerated toward the substrate through a "sheath voltage". The problem is that non-conductive substances can't be etched, unless you use radio frequencies. In the industry, 13 MHz is used, but newer processes are using microwaves. The 13MHz is easier to control (to keep away from the item to be coated), is less hazardous to personnel, and is easier to generate and control efficiently.
You are etching your glass! You may be able to see this under a microscope. Do you ever do glassblowing? The major problem is the "sodium flare' when the glass is being worked in the flame. There are special "didymium" glasses that are worn when doing this work.
Look up high vacuum processes. It is a field as interesting, and diverse, as chemistry! You can work in spaces where a nitrogen molecule must travel 1 meter before hitting another! vtcmag.com (site for magazine)

There are some interesting features of plasma: You may be able to test them:
1) The frequency/color of the light does not really depend on the temperature, but on the chemo-electric activity. Plasma fire can be really cold.
2) The plasma does not really react to magnetic fields only. There are always electric fields (and currents) involved. When currents are applied, magnetic fields can create rotating plasma, or focus plasma.
3) With magnetic fields and electric fields we can see the Zeeman effect and Stark effect respectively.
4) Plasma can cause some redshift of light, depending on the electron density. Also slows down the light. This is hard to test.
5) Substances like ionized helium may create interesting chemical reactions.

Your beaker is not completely closed and the microwave oven has an internal fan to blow air inside. You can see the matches flames moving when the plate turns to a specific position. This means that the gas and smoke are being blown out of the beaker, which disperses the gas and smoke, fizzling out the plasma. Try using a closed vessel for further experiments.

For the plasma not lasting in the first experiment(with matches):

My best guess is that the oxygen in the beaker ran out, and the "CGI Fireball" died off. It is possible that the gases within the fire were turned into plasma, with the other plasma originally in the fire. As the amount of oxygen begin to burn off, as the new plasma may also behave like fire and consume oxygen, the plasma will eventually fizzle out.

Just my take on the situation.

The reason why plasma forms in the presence of metall is that the microwaves induce currents up to 20 A which leads to electrical arcs forming. The generated plasma is then sustained with more energy by the microwaves leading to the big formation of plasma at the top of the beaker. So a completely different process then with the grapes. Also I think that the nitrogen dioxide is rather created through impact ionization or field ionization then through the plasma being at a high temperature. For example you can create high amounts of ozon by utilising dielectric barrier discharge which works at low temperatures by breaking down the oxygen molecule through the electric field.
